definition: France/French/abbr. for 法國|法国[Fa3 guo2]/Taiwan pr. [Fa4]
law/method/way/to emulate/(Buddhism) dharma/(abbr. for 法家[Fa3 jia1]) the Legalists/(physics) farad (abbr. for 法拉[fa3 la1])

sentences.english: Well, violations of the law of nature are an act of aggression.
sentences.chinese: 違反自然法是一種侵略行爲。

sentences.english: Chapter 1 of text is concerning the source of the natural law theory of the Spinoza of.
sentences.chinese: 正文的第一章是關於斯賓諾莎自然法學說的來源問題。

sentences.english: The only reliable basis for sound government and just human relations is natural law.
sentences.chinese: 健全政府和人類之間關係的唯一可靠基礎是自然法。

sentences.english: He prepared the ground for the secular, rationalistic version of modern natural law.
sentences.chinese: 他爲現代自然法世俗的，理性主義的觀點奠定了基礎。

sentences.english: Western natural law theory has a long history and rich content.
sentences.chinese: 西方自然法學說具有悠久的歷史和豐富的內涵。

sentences.english: All this is not to say that natural-law concepts have no role to play in constitutional interpretation.
sentences.chinese: 這樣說並不表示自然法的觀念在釋憲工作上沒有意義。

sentences.english: That is the nature of life.
sentences.chinese: 這正是人生的自然法則。

sentences.english: Since man are higher animals, they should observe this natural principle.
sentences.chinese: 人即然是高等動物，當然也應該遵守這一自然法則。

sentences.english: Ontology behind the search for natural law, so that John Wu to God.
sentences.chinese: 追尋自然法背後的本體，使吳經熊走向了上帝。

sentences.english: If someone violates the law of nature, he is an aggressor.
sentences.chinese: 如果某人觸犯了自然法，他就是侵略者。

sentences.english: Such explanations of the natural order felt most unnatural at first.
sentences.chinese: 這種對自然法則的解釋起初讓我感覺很不自然。

sentences.english: What is the status of the laws of nature?
The main inconvenience is that everyone can enforce the law of nature.
sentences.chinese: 主要的一點就是每個人都能行使自然法。

sentences.english: Even though I am free, I'm not free to violate the law of nature.
sentences.chinese: 即使我是自由的，我也不能隨意違背自然法。

definition: deism, theological theory of God who does not interfere in the Universe
Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel (1770-1831), German philosopher
epistemology (in philosophy, the theory of how we know things)
dualism, belief that the universe is made of two different substance (e.g. mind and matter or good and evil)
Baruch or Benedict Spinoza (1632-1677), rationalist philosopher
